"With whom do you find it easiest to make friends?" (opposite sex, same sex or no difference).

ul.li: Learn how to tally our data into a table of counts and percentages.
Learn how to produce a pie chart.

alternative.title: R Instructions
alternative.p: To open R with the dataset preloaded, right-click here and choose "Save Target As" to download the file to your computer. Then find the downloaded file and double-click it to open it in R.
The data have been loaded into the data frame friends. Enter the command friends to see the data.
You can scroll up and down to see how 1,200 men and women answered the question: "With whom do you find it easiest to make friends?"

Notice that the column title in the data frame friends is Friends. The column title Friends is the variable name, while the data frame name is friends. The subtle difference is the capital F in the column title. R is sensitive to capitalization so R identifies friends and Friends as two different things. To extract a specific variable from a data frame there are many methods, the simplest method is to use the $ to identify the desired variable (column title) within the data frame, or friends$Friends.

Obviously the raw data is not very useful so we will summarize it using a table. To get a summary table of the data, copy and paste the next commands into R (and press Enter if necessary to execute the command):
Note: Using R—When you assign a value to a variable, R will not display the value unless you ask for the display by executing the variable name as a command in the console.

The same method is used below when the summary table for Friends is converted to percentages and assigned to the variable percent. Executing the variable name to see its contents may seem like an unnecessary extra step, but the convention allows you to assign a large amount of data to a variable and not fill your screen with the result (which could be millions of numbers) unless you really want to see it.

alternative.title: StatCrunch Instructions
alternative.p: To open this file in StatCrunch, you must first right-click here and choose "Save Target As" to download the file to your computer. Next, click here to open StatCrunch in a separate window, and log in using your username and password.

ul.li: Click on the link “Open StatCrunch” at the top of the My StatCrunch page.
To open the dataset, choose Data → Load → From file → on my computer.
Select "Browse" or “Choose File” (depending on which browser you're using), and select the dataset you downloaded.
Scroll to the bottom of the page and click on “Load File.”

alternative.p: To ask StatCrunch for a table of counts and percentages:

ul.li: Choose Stat → Tables → Frequency.
In the Frequency Table window, select the column Friends.
Press Compute! (The information will appear in a pop-up window.)

alternative.p: To ask StatCrunch for a pie chart of the data:

ul.li: Choose Graph → Pie Chart → with data.
In the Pie Chart With Data window, select column Friends.
Press Compute! (Pie chart will appear in a pop-up window.)

alternative.title: Minitab Instructions
alternative.p: To open Minitab with the data in the worksheet, right-click here and choose "Save Target As" to download the file to your computer. Then find the downloaded file and double-click it to open it in Minitab. Note: you will likely see a dialog box appear that says "A copy of the content of this file will be added to the current project"—just click OK.
To ask Minitab for a table of counts and percentages:

ul.li: Choose: Stat → Tables → Tally Individual Variables.
Under "Variables" type friends (or double-click on this variable in the left panel).
Under "Display," check "Counts" and "Percents."
Click OK (The information will appear in the session (upper) window).

alternative.p: To ask Minitab for a pie chart of the data:

ul.li: Choose: Graph → Pie Chart.
Under "Categorical variables," type "Friends" (or double-click on this variable in the left panel).
Click on "Labels," choose the "Slice Labels" tab on top, and check "Frequency" and "Percent."
Click OK twice. A separate window with the pie chart will show up.

alternative.title: Excel 2013 and 2016 Instructions
alternative.p: To open the dataset, click here to download the file to your computer. Then find the downloaded file and double-click it to open it in Excel. When Excel opens you may have to enable editing.
To ask Excel for a table of counts and percentages:

ul.li: Click on the cell with the variable label Friends.
Click on the arrow under PivotTable in the Tables group in the Insert tab, and choose Pivot Table from the drop-down menu.
Click OK.
Excel will create a new worksheet with a blank table. We have to tell Excel how to construct the table:
You should see a window titled PivotTable Field List with a single item that is our "Friends" variable.
Check the box next to Friends.
Now drag the Friends item to the table where it says Drop Value Fields Here.

alternative.p: You should now have a table that shows the number of each type of data entry—"No difference," "Opposite sex," and "Same sex,"—and a grand total. This is the count of each of these entries. To see the percents for each entry, we can ask Excel to show percents instead of counts:

ul.li: Right-click on any of the cells containing the counts and choose Value Field Settings from the pop-up menu.
Click the tab that says Show values as.
Now use the drop-down menu labeled Show data as: to select % of total and click OK.

alternative.p: To produce a pie chart of the data using Excel:

ul.li: First, if your table is showing percents, you need to change it back to counts:
Right-click on any of the cells containing the percents and choose Value Field Settings from the pop-up menu.
Click the tab that says Show values as.
Now use the drop-down menu labeled Show values as: to select No Calculation and click OK.
Now click on one of the cells in your table and then click the PivotChart button in the Tools group on the Analyze (PivotTable Tools) tab.
In the Insert Chart window that appears, choose the first pie chart option and click OK.
To label the sections of the pie, right click the pie and choose Format Data Labels (version 2013) or Add Data Labels (version 2016) from the pop-up menu.
To see percentages as well as absolute values, right-click the pie and choose Format Data Labels from the pop-up menu. On the menu that appears to the right, check the box next to Percentage.

alternative.title: TI Instructions
alternative.p: Important Note! TI 83/84 calculators do not have the built-in capability to create a table of counts and percentages or to construct a pie chart. Thus, for this activity, we suggest trying one of the other technologies available in OLI Statistics. R is an excellent statistical package that is free to download and that is available for both Windows and Mac OS X.
If you want to continue with the TI Calculator, you can produce a table of counts and percentages by hand using your TI to help. You can download an app that will allow you to construct a pie chart.

To open a group of lists with the survey data loaded, right-click here and choose "Save Target As" to download the file to your computer. Then find the downloaded file and send it to your calculator. For instructions on how to connect your calculator to your computer and transfer a file, click here.
Since the dataset is too large (n=1,200) to store in one list, the 1,200 values are split into two lists.
The friends data should now be loaded in L1 and L2, and is coded as follows: 0=no difference, 1=opposite sex, 2=same sex.
You can produce a table of counts or percents by hand using your TI to help.
First, sort the lists (L1 and L2) that contain the coded data for the categorical variable in ascending order:

ul.li: Choose STAT/EDIT/2:SortA(
You should see:

Before pressing ENTER, choose the list that you want to sort:
To access one of the built-in lists (L1-L6), press 2ND and then the number of the list. For example, to access L1, you would press 2ND/1.
To access a non-built-in list, use the LIST menu (2ND/STAT). Press LIST/NAMES to choose the appropriate list.
Press the right parenthesis, then ENTER.
You should see:
Check out the sorted list by choosing STAT/EDIT/1:Edit.

alternative.p: Count the number of values for each category.
The page One Categorical Variable (1 of 3) describes how to create a table with counts and percentages.

While the TI Calculator does not have the built-in capability to create a pie chart, you can download an app for your calculator that will do this. It is called CellSheet App and is a free download from the TI website. Note that some TI calculators have the CellSheet App preloaded—choose APPS on your TI to see if CellSheet App is already loaded on your calculator.
The TI website also includes instructions for downloading apps to your TI and an example exercise that shows how to construct a pie chart.
Once you have CellSheet App installed, use it to create a pie chart on the TI:

ul.li: Press APPS.
Choose Cellsheet.
Press any key twice to get to the spreadsheet screen.
Press GRAPH to access the CellSheet menu.
Choose 1:File
Choose 3:New
Name the spreadsheet and press ENTER.
Press ENTER again.

Now enter the labels for the pie chart in row 1, starting in column A.
Use the arrow keys to position the cursor in A1.
Choose A-LOCK (2ND/ALPHA)
Press " (found over the + key), then continue pressing the letters for a name for the first category. Press ENTER when finished.
Your cursor should be in A2.
Enter the percentage for the first category.
Repeat for each category of the categorical variable.
You should see:
Choose the Menu by pressing GRAPH.
Choose 4: Charts.
Choose 7:Pie
You should see:

For Categories: enter the range for the category labels, ex. A1:C1
Press ALPHA/MATH for the A, then press the number 1.
Press ALPHA/. for the : (press ALPHA and a decimal point to get a colon)
Press ALPHA/APPS for the C, then press the number 1.
Press ENTER or the down arrow to move to the next line.
For Series: enter the range of the percentages of each category, or A2:C2
Choose Percent by highlighting Percent and pressing ENTER.
Enter a Title:. Alpha-lock is automatically on, so press up to 10 letters for a title.
You should see:
Choose DRAW and press ENTER.
Choose TRACE and use arrows to investigate the different categories for the pie chart.
Note: you can enter counts instead of percentages if you prefer.

body.p: Note that the pie chart visually provides all the information that is in the table.
